--- title: "Randomization (Permutations) Tests" date-modified: "2024-10-22" --- Randomization tests, also known as permutation tests, are used to test the null hypothesis is **R Packages and Functions Used** ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-fold="false"} library(tidyverse) library(palmerpenguins) theme_set(theme_bw()) theme_update(axis.title = element_text(size = 24)) shuffle <- function(x){ n <- length(x) return(sample(x, n)) } penguins <- penguins |> drop_na() ``` ::: ## Permutation Tests Permutation tests conducts a statistical test by constructing the null distribution by rearranging the data points in a sample. Null hypothesis states that the rearrangements of the data points **are** random. Alternative hypothesis states that the rearrangement of the data points **aren't** random. ## Permutation Distributions :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="50%"} ### Null $$ F_x = F_y $$ ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} ### Alternative $$ F_x \neq F_y $$ ::: :::: Suppose $\{X_i, Y_i\}^n_{i=1}$ is an observed permutation, $X = \{X_1, \ldots, X_n\}$, $Y = \{Y_1, \ldots, Y_n\}$. The Probability of any permuation is $1/n!$. Therefore, for a statistic $T(X,Y)$, a sampling distribution can be constructed by all the different permutations. A hypothesis test can be conducted by observing the proportion of more extreme values of the sample statistic. ## Approximate Permutation Distribution Constructing the distribution for the permutations can be challenging if the number of permutations is high! If $n=100$, the number of permutations is $100!$: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-fold="false"} factorial(100) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` #> [1] 9.332622e+157 ``` ::: ::: Therefore, simulation techniques are needed to approximate the p-value. By randomly drawing from the sample, we can approximate the p-value. ### Algorithm 1. Construct a new data set 1. Fix the predictor ($X$) variable and randomly assign a data point $Y$ to the fixed $X$ 2. Compute a test statistic using the new data set and store the value 3. Repeat steps 1 and 2 for $N$ times 4. Compute the test statistic from the empirical sample (un-permutated) 5. Count how many permutated statistics that are more extreme than the sample test statistic ($m$) 6. Compute the Monte Carlo p-value $$ p = \frac{m +1}{N + 1} $$ ## Example: Emperical Data ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-fold="true"} penguins |> ggplot(aes(x=species, y = body_mass_g)) + geom_boxplot() + geom_jitter() + labs(x = "Species", y = "Body Mass") ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](randomizations_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-3-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ### Example: Random
